questions.text: A 20-year-old female patient presented with a complaint of heaviness inside left ear and decreased hearing since 3 months. Endoscopic picture of the affected ear is shown below. Impedence audiometry was done suggestive of type b curve. Which of the following statements is true for this condition?
questions.solution:
Based on the endoscopic picture and type b curve on impedance audiometry the diagnosis in this case is serous otitis media.

It's management primarily includes antihistamines, and decongestants.

But if the condition does not resolve even after 3 months than Myringotomy is performed followed by placement of a grommet tube or tympanostomy tube to maintain ventilation.

Option A: The collected fluid in the middle ear impairs the function of impedance matching of the middle ear and usually does not affect the inner ear. Thus it leads to conductive deafness. Hence option A is also not true.

Option C: Also since it's sterile fluid collection the chances of bone erosion and developing an intracranial abscess is negligible thus option c is not true.

Option D: It is defined as the collection of sterile fluid in the middle ear. So on aspiration of this fluid no organisms are usually isolated hence option d is not true.

Key takeaway:

SOM Management: Initial Conservative for 3 months - If Fails - Myringotomy and Grommet Insertion.

Image reference: Toronto notes website.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male patient presented with unilateral conductive hearing loss, fullness in ear since 1 month. On examination the endoscopic picture is given below. What will be the next step of management?
questions.solution:
The adult man in this case is presented with unilateral conductive hearing loss, Moreover the endoscopic picture is suggestive of serous otitis media.

Any adult person presenting with unilateral SOM should be first investigated for nasopharyngeal mass.

Only after ruling out a nasopharyngeal mass conservative management for SOM should be given.

Conservative management is first given in the form of antihistamines and decongestants.

If the condition does not resolve within 3 weeks of medical management then surgical management is done.

Surgical management includes Myringotomy with grommet insertion is done.

Option A: Myringotomy and Grommet Insertion is done but after Ruling Out Nasopharyngeal mass And when Conservative treatment fails.

Option C: Antibiotics has no role in management of SOM as It's sterile condition.

Option D: Only Observation will not suffice in symptomatic adult patients.

Key takeaway:

Any adult person presenting with unilateral SOM should be first investigated for nasopharyngeal mass. Only after ruling out a nasopharyngeal mass conservative management for SOM should be given.

Image reference: Dr Meenesh javekar website.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male patient presents with foul smelling ear discharge. Discharge was scanty in nature, patient also experience vertigo intermittently. HRCT temporal bone was done which is suggestive of cholesteatoma in epitympanum and mesotympanum with erosion of incus. On endoscopy, the tympanic membrane appeared as the picture given below. Most appropriate next step in management is?
questions.solution:
The picture shown above is suggestive of attic retraction pocket with cholesteatoma flakes.

Cholesteatoma is presence of keratinizing stratified squamous epithelium in any part of temporal bone where it is usually not present. Eg middle ear, mastoid, petrous Apex.

In its basal layer, cholesteatoma has got enzymes like collagenase and acid phosphatase which cause the bony erosion, helping the middle ear infection to reach the surrounding areas, leading to various complications.

Patient present here with scant, painless and foul smelling discharge because of otitis and bone erosion by cholesteatoma and infection with anaerobic organism.

The main management of unsafe CSOM is mastoid exploration with removal of disease from the mastoid, followed by removal of disease from middle ear.

Option A: Discharge in unsafe otitis media is mainly because of bone erosion hence medical management with local and systemic antibiotics does not have much affect on drying of discharge.

Option C: Only Myringoplasty is not sufficient in eradicating the disease from middle ear and mastoid cavity.

Option D: Radical mastoidectomy is indicated in extensive cholesteatoma following unsafe csom with dead ear.

Unresectable cholesteatoma extending upto petrous Apex, promontory cochlear fistula.

Key Takeaway:

Unsafe CSOM Management - Modified Radical Mastoidectomy. No role of medical management

Image reference: ent Nepal website.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male patient presented with complain of 6 months of ear discharge, discharge was non foul smelling, it is associated with hearing loss. Endoscopy picture is given below. Patient was undertaken for tympanoplasty. During surgery it was found that malleus handle was present but incus and stapes suprastructure are absent. What will be the grade of defect in this patient according to Austin's classification?
questions.solution:
The picture shown above is suggestive of Tubotympanic Type of CSOM.

According to Austin's classification, ossicular erosion are graded into four types depending upon presence or absence of malleus handle M and stapes supra structure S.

Type A M+S+: both malleus handle and stapes suprastructure are present.

Type B M+ S-: Malleus handle is present but incus and stapes suprastructure are absent.

Type C M-S+: Malleus handle is absent but stapes suprastructure is present.

Type D M-S-: All the ossicles are missing.

Key Takeaway:

questions.text: A 22 year male patient with a known case of CSOM attico antral type develops Gradenigo syndrome. Which of the following symptoms will not be a part of Gradenigo syndrome?
questions.solution:
Options A, C, D: The air cells of petrous part of temporal bone communicate with the mastoid bone. Thus, infection in the mastoid region can transmit to petrous bone, leading to persistent ear discharge.

The 6th cranial nerve runs in the Dorello's canal at the petrous Apex and the 5th nerve lies in the Meckel's canal.

So there is palsy of 6th nerve leading to diplopia. Involvement of ophthalmic division of trigeminal nerve leads to retro bulbar pain.

Option B: Facial nerve is not involved in petrositis thus it is not a part of Gradenigo syndrome.

Key Takeaway:

Gradenigo Triad Characterised by Persistent ear Discharge, Diplopia and Retrobulbar Pain seen in apical petrositis.

questions.text: A 45-year-old female patient presented with complain of ear discharge and giddiness since 2 years. Ear endoscopy picture is given below. She was diagnosed as having primary Cholesteatoma. Which of the following is not a theory of primary Cholesteatoma formation?
questions.solution:
There are two type of theories for formation of acquired Cholesteatoma

Primary Cholesteatoma and secondary Cholesteatoma

Theories of primary Cholesteatoma are:

  1. Wittmaack's theory: This is the most accepted theory. The obstruction of Eustachian tube creates negative pressure in the middle ear and retraction of TM.
    Persistence of this negative pressure leads to formation of retraction pocket.
    Keratin debris accumulates in this pocket. It leads to activation of osteoclasts and releases enzymes like acid phosphatase, collagenase etc.
  2. SADE's theory: Because of the repeated infection of middle ear through Eustachian tube, the epithelium of middle ear undergoes metaplasia. And changes to stratified squamous epithelium.
  3. Ruedi's theory: Following repeated infection the basal epithelium cells of outer layer of TM proliferates and invades sub epithelium tissue. The proliferating keratinocytes invades through the basal lamina.

Theory of secondary Cholesteatoma:

  1. Habermann's theory: There is migration of keratinizing stratified squamous epithelium of the external auditory canal through the marginal perforation of tympanic membrane into middle ear. (Option C)

Key Takeaway:

Theories of Cholesteatoma:

Primary

  1. Wittmaack's - Retraction pocket
  2. Sade's - Squamous metaplasia
  3. Ruedi's - Basal Hyperplasia

Secondary - Habermann's epithelium migration theory

Image reference: Sydney ENT clinic website.

questions.text: A 35-year-old patient complaints of 6 months of non foul smelling ear discharge and hearing loss. The endoscopic picture is given below. He underwent myringoplasty for it. Which of the following is true?
questions.solution:
Based on the clinical picture and symptoms, the diagnosis in this case is CSOM Tubotympanic Type. Surgical repair of tympanic membrane is called myringoplasty.

Here the perforation is repaired by a graft which is most commonly taken from the fascia overlying the temporalis muscle.

There are two techniques: overlay and underlay. These terms refer to position of the graft in relation to fibrous annulus and not to the malleus.

In overlay technique, the squamous epithelium layer of TM is raised, keeping the fibrous layer along with annulus in place.

The fascia Lata graft is placed lateral to the middle fibrous layer of TM and annulus.

In underlay technique, the entire TM along with the annulus is raised. The fascia Lata graft is then placed medial to TM and annulus.

Option B & C: Both are Medial / Deep to Malleus

Option D: In overlay graft, the graft is placed Lateral to the annulus.

Key takeaway:

Named after Fibrous Annulus. Not Malleus (Both are Medial to Malleus)

Image reference: sports medicine review website.

questions.text: A 3-year-old female patient presented with underdeveloped ear pinna on the right side as shown in the picture. HRCT temporal bone shows the underlying external auditory canal, middle ear and inner ear are normal. What is the correct age for surgical reconstruction of pinna in this case?
questions.solution:
The condition shown in this picture is called microtia.

It is important to remember that the surgical reconstruction of ear pinna in microtia is done at or after 6 years of age for two reasons.

  1. Autologous coastal cartilage (rib) cartilage is used as graft. The coastal cartilage gets developed enough for this purpose by the age of 6 years.
  2. Pinna attains almost the adult size by 6 years. So the side which is to be reconstructed can be compared with the normal side pinna.

Pinna develops from 1st and 2nd brachial arch mesoderm gives rise to 6 mesodermal thickenings known as hillock of his which fuse to form pinna.

The failure of development in 1st or 2nd arch or both leads to defect like microtia and anotia.

Integration:

Age Period in ENT:

  • Cochlear implant before 1 year
  • Meatoplasty - 6 years
  • Septoplasty - 17 years

Key Takeaway:

2 Reasons for Meatoplasty at 6 years:

  1. Autologous costal cartilage (rib) cartilage is used as graft. The costal cartilage gets developed enough for this purpose by the age of 6 years.
  2. Pinna attains almost the adult size by 6 years. So the side which is to be reconstructed can be compared with the normal side pinna.

Image reference: Reinisch plastic surgery website.

questions.text: A 30-year-old female patient presented with complain of ear heaviness and decreased hearing. The complaints didn't resolve by medical management. Surgery was done and an incision was given on the tympanic membrane. Picture of the radial Incision is given below. This incision is given in which condition?
questions.solution:
As shown in the picture, a radial incision is placed on the antero inferior quadrant of the tympanic membrane.

The name of the surgery is called Myringotomy. This surgery is performed in cases of serous otitis media.

In most cases, a device called grommet is also placed through the incision.

It is important to note that Myringotomy is also performed in acute suppurative otitis media.

But here the incision is placed in the postero-inferior quadrant. The incision in the ASOM is curvilinear. (Option A)

Myringotomy is never done in the postero superior quadrant to avoid injury to chorda tympani nerve, facial nerve, incudostapedial joint and oval window.

Mnemonic: postero superior Myringotomy are: chorda tympani, facial nerve, Incudo stapedial joint, and oVal window. Preventive and social medicine (PSM) is about Children, female and Immunization overall.

Key Takeaway:

Myringotomy Incision

  1. Curvilinear in Posteroinferior - ASOM
  2. Radial in anteroinferior - SOM
  3. Never done at Posterosuperior.

Image reference: Medscape.

questions.text: All of the following are the type of grommet except?
questions.solution:
Grommet is a device which provides ventilation to the middle ear temporarily. It effectively replaces Eustachian tube in case of SOM.

According to the duration for which the grommet stays, it have been divided into:

  • Short term: stay <6 months. These are Shepard and Donaldson grommets.
  • Mid term: stay for 6 months to 2 years . They are shah, Armstrong grommet.
  • Long term: Goldie T tube, Per Lee tube.

Key Takeaway:

Frenzel is Maneuver in Eustachian tube Function test.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male patient presented with complain of left ear discharge with dull ear ache since 7 years. On examination Tympanic membrane is intact with discharge coming from posterior canal wall. Endoscopic picture is given below. Hearing is normal. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Based on clinical findings and endoscopic picture the diagnosis in this case is keratosis obturans.

Faulty migration pattern or obstruction of epithelium migration can lead to collection of dense plug of pearly white mass of desquamated epithelial cells in the EAC.

Clinical features: it is common in young. Keratin plug can completely occlude the EAC in a laminar onion skin pattern.

It causes widening of EAC due to build up pressure. Patient presents with dull aching pain, ear discharge.

Management: By local debridement of keratin plug.

Option B: CSOM is a disease of the middle ear with foul smelling discharge and bone erosion.

Option C: Complications of otitis externa May include facial cellulitis, osteomyelitis or intracranial spread.

Option D: Carcinoma present with ulcerative growth with bony erosion & Soft tissue involvement.

Key Takeaway:

Image reference: Dr Ajay Jain website.

questions.text: A 25-year-old female patient presented with complain of ear discharge, ear ache and ear itching. On examination the ear shows the following picture. What is the appropriate management in this case?
questions.solution:
Based on clinical findings and picture the diagnosis in this case is otomycosis.

Otomycosis is the fungal infection of external auditory canal. It is seen in hot and humid climate.

Aspergillus Niger is the most common organism causing otomycosis followed by candida. Aspergillus infection have the appearance of moist white plugs dotted with black debris (wet newspaper appearance).

Candida infection appears like a cotton like debris. Patient presents with ear itching, ear ache, discharge and blockage.

Management is by ear toileting and antifungal (Clotrimazole) ear drops.

Option A: Ciprofloxacin drops used in otitis externa due to bacterial etiology.

Option B: Wax softening drops Useful in impacted wax.

Option C: Steroid drops may help in inflammatory conditions

Key Takeaway:

Otomycosis - Managed with Antifungal drops.

  • Wet newspaper - Aspergillus
  • Cotton debris - Candida

Image reference: life world wide website.
